articles.headline: Jury Decides for Greenberg in A.I.G. Case Over Shares
articles.snippet: In an advisory decision, a federal jury found that Maurice Greenberg, its former chief, did not wrongly take billions in A.I.G. stock.
articles.abstract: In an advisory decision, a federal jury found that Maurice Greenberg, its former chief, did not wrongly take billions in A.I.G. stock.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal jury ruled on Tuesday that Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, did not wrongly seize $4.3 billion in company stock.

articles.headline: Staggering Budget Gap and a Reluctance to Fill It
articles.snippet: The potential perils of Washington’s staggering deficits are known, but trying to overcome them during a recession carries its own risks.
articles.abstract: The potential perils of Washington’s staggering deficits are known, but trying to overcome them during a recession carries its own risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: No one argues that the staggering deficits run up by the American government in a bid to rescue the economy are desirable, healthy or even sustainable  not if the national debt continues to swell at its current pace. But considerable debate centers on when and how vigorously to start easing off Washington’s borrowing habit, with substantial risks at both extremes.

articles.headline: Lights, Camera, Lots of Action. Forget the Script.
articles.snippet: With pornographic movies being sold online in chunks, moviemakers are now even less interested in story lines.
articles.abstract: With pornographic movies being sold online in chunks, moviemakers are now even less interested in story lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: The actress known as Savanna Samson once relished preparing for a role. “I couldn’t wait to get my next script,” she said.

articles.headline: In Health Reform, a Cancer Offers an Acid Test
articles.snippet: The fundamental problem with America’s medical system is the mix of soaring costs and mediocre results.
articles.abstract: The fundamental problem with America’s medical system is the mix of soaring costs and mediocre results.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  It’s become popular to pick your own personal litmus test for health care reform.

articles.headline: Sending GPS Devices the Way of the Tape Deck?
articles.snippet: The smartphone is beginning to displace the GPS receiver as a convenient way for drivers to get directions to unknown destinations.
articles.abstract: The smartphone is beginning to displace the GPS receiver as a convenient way for drivers to get directions to unknown destinations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The smartphone is already the Swiss Army knife of the digital age  a quick flick of the finger can transform it into a camcorder, Web browser, gaming device or music player. For many consumers, the Apple iPhone and its competitors are versatile enough that they can get by without separate cameras and laptops.

articles.headline: In Summer Hideaway for the Rich, Slump Is Visiting, Too
articles.snippet: On Nantucket, businesses are struggling and home sales are slow as the recession creeps into an exclusive enclave.
articles.abstract: On Nantucket, businesses are struggling and home sales are slow as the recession creeps into an exclusive enclave.
articles.lead_paragraph: NANTUCKET, Mass.  On a winding road, down a white shell driveway, sits a rambling gray-shingled home with a view of the harbor, where beige lounge chairs ring an amoeba-shaped swimming pool and the living room is filled with pristinely white sofas, plumped, pillowed  ready for the next owners.

articles.headline: Google Plans a PC Operating System
articles.snippet: Google announced it is developing an operating system for personal computers, a direct challenge to Microsoft.
articles.abstract: Google announced it is developing an operating system for personal computers, a direct challenge to Microsoft.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  In a direct challenge to Microsoft, Google announced late Tuesday that it is developing an operating system for PCs that is tied to its Chrome Web browser.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Ashlee Vance

articles.headline: Poorer Nations Reject a Target on Emission Cut
articles.snippet: The lack of consensus on cuts in heat-trapping gases at the Group of 8 talks underscored the divisions between developed and developing nations.
articles.abstract: The lack of consensus on cuts in heat-trapping gases at the Group of 8 talks underscored the divisions between developed and developing nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: L’AQUILA, Italy  The world’s biggest developing nations, led by China and India, refused Wednesday to commit to specific goals for slashing heat-trapping gases by 2050, undercutting the drive to build a global consensus by the end of this year to reverse the threat of climate change.
